channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Dying Infants and No Medicine: Inside Venezuela’s Failing Hospitals
item.media:description: Yulitza Roa, 15, who has a brain tumor, is awaiting surgery that has been delayed because Luis Razetti Hospital does not have the needed scanning equipment.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: Supplies are lacking, electricity goes out, equipment is broken and patients lie in pools of blood as the country’s economic crisis has exploded into a public health emergency.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Colombia and FARC Rebels Reach a Deal to Free Child Soldiers
item.description: The government and the rebel group known as FARC said on Sunday that they had an agreement that could involve hundreds of children.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Kabul Journal: Attacks in Kabul Keep Wall Builders Busy, Turning City Into Labyrinth
item.media:description: Artists painted a mural on a blast wall in front of an Afghan National Police post in Kabul in March. Some blast walls in the city are 20 feet tall.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: Bombings in Afghanistan’s capital have led companies to build taller blast walls, which blend into the landscape as part of the city’s identity.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: ‘I Will Kill Him’: Afghan Commander Targets Son, a Taliban Fighter
item.description: The determination of Abdul Basir to kill his 22-year-old son is a sign of how Afghanistan’s violence has poisoned the closest of relationships.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Palestinian Museum Prepares to Open, Minus Exhibits
item.media:description: Visitors last week at the new Palestinian Museum in Birzeit in the West Bank. It will open its doors on Wednesday despite being empty.
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.description: A $24 million building will open in the West Bank on Wednesday, but its inaugural display was suspended after a disagreement between its board and its director, who lost his position.
item.dc:creator: JAMES GLANZ and RAMI NAZZAL

item.title: Al Qaeda Turns to Syria, With a Plan to Challenge ISIS
item.media:description: The Qaeda leader Ayman al-Zawahri in a 2011 image provided by the SITE Intelligence Group. He seemed to clear the way this month for Qaeda figures to use the group’s Syrian affiliate, the Nusra Front, to form an emirate there.
item.description: The group’s leadership in Pakistan has secretly dispatched seasoned veterans there to create an alternate headquarters and compete with the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Long Emphasis on Terror May Hurt U.S. in Conventional War, Army Chief Says
item.media:description: Members of Chad’s army trained with American Special Forces last year.
item.description: On his way to talks in Africa, Gen. Mark A. Milley, the Army chief of staff, said that troops who began training after Sept. 11, 2001, knew “nothing but fighting terrorists and guerrillas.”
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Swedish Court Sentences Man to Life in Prison for Role in Rwanda Genocide
item.media:description: Claver Berinkindi, second from right, in court in Stockholm in September. Mr. Berinkindi received a life sentence from a Stockholm District Court for his participation in the 1994 genocide in Rwanda.
item.description: The Stockholm District Court found that Claver Berinkindi, who obtained Swedish citizenship in 2012, had participated in five massacres in 1994
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA ANDERSON
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Letter From Europe: Cloak of Secrecy Fuels Anxiety Over Trans-Atlantic Trade Talks
item.media:description: A protest in Brussels against the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership. Opponents are pushing for greater transparency in the trade talks.
item.description: European opposition to a sweeping trade deal involving the United States has focused on the confidentiality surrounding the talks.
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Vote Worries European Up-and-Comers Lured to Britain
item.media:description: Silvia Luis, who is from Portugal, came to London eight months ago to study criminal psychology. She said she is desperate to stay in Britain.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: London has long been a destination for young workers from the Continent. Many are scrambling to find ways to stay if Britain leaves the European Union.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Sinosphere: Readers Respond: The Cultural Revolution’s Lasting Imprint
item.media:description: Red Guards, bands of young militants mobilized by Mao Zedong as a vanguard of the Cultural Revolution, filing through Tiananmen Square in Beijing in October 1966.
item.media:credit: Visual China Group, via Getty Images
item.description: Here are some recollections from readers when asked how their families were affected by the Cultural Revolution, a decade of political upheaval unleashed by Mao Zedong half a century ago.

item.title: Huge Protest Against Afghan Government Brings Kabul to a Halt
item.description: With factional tensions already high, ethnic Hazara protesters said a move to reroute an electricity transmission line was biased against them.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Syria Allows Students to Leave Rebel-Held Areas to Take Exams
item.description: The government, eager to show it can still provide services in areas it does not control, has allowed hundreds of students to leave besieged areas.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: After Years of Distrust, U.S. Military Reconciles With Nigeria to Fight Boko Haram
item.media:description: President Obama meeting with President Muhammadu Buhari of Nigeria in the Oval Office in July.
item.description: Nigeria’s new president has focused on eliminating corruption in the military and, although doubts remain, the U.S. is ready to sell 12 warplanes to Nigeria.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and DIONNE SEARCEY
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Memo From Austria: Long Dominated by Center, Austria Splinters to Left and Right
item.media:description: Campaign posters for Norbert Hofer of the far-right Freedom Party near Nickelsdorf, Austria. Mr. Hofer will face Alexander Van der Bellen, a former Green Party leader, in a presidential runoff election next Sunday.
item.description: Austria’s presidential runoff on May 22 could be a test of how far voters will go to demand change as immigration and economic stress create a combustible mix.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Manchester United Match Canceled After Fake Bomb Is Found
item.description: The police determined that a training device from a security exercise had been left behind at the stadium.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: The Vaquita, the World’s Smallest Porpoise, Slips Closer to Extinction
item.media:description: The Mexican government has deployed fast boats, planes, helicopters and even drones to patrol for illegal fishermen.
item.description: Scientists say only about 60 are left in the Gulf of California, threatened by nets that fishermen illegally use to catch totoaba, a source of a Chinese delicacy.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: François Morellet, French Abstract Artist, Dies at 90
item.media:description: François Morellet in front of light installations at the Centre Pompidou in 2011.
item.description: Mr. Morellet, who used unorthodox materials and incorporated kinetics in his sculptures, sought to make art that would “make it possible for the observer to find what he wants.”
item.dc:creator: HANNAH OLIVENNES

item.title: What in the World: The Mountain That Tops Everest (Because the Earth Is Fat)
item.media:description: Earth flattens at its poles and bulges slightly around its waistline, making its radius about 13 miles greater at the Equator.
item.description: Mount Chimborazo in Ecuador rises about 20,500 feet above sea level, far short of Everest’s 29,029 feet. But it’s a different story when you measure from the center of the earth.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: What in the World: Japan Has a Kit Kat for Every Taste, and Then Some
item.media:credit: Illustration by Craig Allen; Photos by Nestlé Japan
item.description: There are nearly 300 varieties of Kit Kat in Japan, where the candy is so popular that it is sold at high-end department stores, Kit Kat-only shops and even post offices.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: What in the World: The Wrong Day to Be a Cat in Belgium
item.media:credit: Illustration by Cari Vander Yacht; Photo by Inna Astakhova / shutterstock.com
item.description: The people of Ypres, Belgium, once dealt with feral cats by throwing them off a bell tower. Today, they host a cat-themed celebration instead.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK J. LYONS

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Know-Nothing Tide
item.description: Trump says America was strongest when “politics ended at water's edge.” He's wrong.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Why Putin Tolerates Corruption
item.description: The West thinks it is the Russian president’s Achilles’ heel. It’s more like his shield.
item.dc:creator: IVAN KRASTEV

item.title: Opinion: Life as a North Korean Refugee
item.description: China should reverse its policy of hunting down defectors and returning them to its brutal neighbor.
item.dc:creator: HYEONSEO LEE

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: On the Ground in Aleppo: Bloodshed, Misery and Hope
item.media:description: A civilian evacuated a baby on Friday from a site that had been hit by airstrikes in a rebel-controlled area of Aleppo, Syria. Inhabitants of the city carry on with work and school despite fighting that has killed more than 200 civilians in the past week.
item.description: The New York Times’s Cairo bureau chief reported from Aleppo, Syria, where inhabitants try to carry on despite a civil war’s inescapable reality.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
